I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The proposed knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) cluster will help build the 
capacity of Asian Development Bank (ADB) developing member countries (DMCs) to enhance 
water security and resilience in Asia and the Pacific. It will (i) support increased climate resilience 
in water projects, programs, and policies by facilitating a shift toward climate-resilient and low-
carbon development; and (ii) help build the capacity of DMC clients to use information and 
communication technology (ICT), digital and remote sensing technologies, and innovations. The 
TA cluster is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030, particularly operational priorities 2 (gender 
equality and women’s empowerment), 3 (tackling climate change, building climate and disaster 
resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability), 4 (making cities more livable), and 5 
(rural development and food security).1 The TA is included in the 2021 ADB Management-
approved  results-based  work  plan  of  the  Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change 
Department (SDCC) and in the Water Sector Group (WSG) work plan, 2021–2022.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Sector challenges. Climate change threatens achievements in economic development, 
improved livelihoods, well-being, and water security for millions of people across Asia and the 
Pacific.3 As the most disaster-affected region in the world, Asia and the Pacific is home to more 
than 40% of disasters triggered by natural hazards and 84% of the people they affect. Climate 
change  will  alter  ecosystem  services’  benefits,  have  detrimental  health  impacts,  stimulate 
migration, and possibly lead to conflicts. These changes disproportionately affect the poor, 
women, children, and the elderly.3 Many ADB DMCs with limited resources are extremely 
susceptible to climate change impacts and lack investment and policy development to address 
climate adaptation. 
 
3.  Water is the primary medium through which the effects of climate change are felt. Effects 
may include increased, more intense, and frequent flooding; storm surges; and increased and 
prolonged droughts. The direct impacts on water resources and water, sanitation, and hygiene 
are already present across Asia and the Pacific and will continue to grow, threatening sustainable 
and inclusive prosperity in the region. The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has also 
highlighted the linkages between water, sanitation, and hygiene; climate resilience; and health. 
Climate change may also affect the chance of water-related disasters striking during pandemics 
and epidemics, compounding their impacts.4 
 
4.  Contribution  to  global  commitments.  The  TA  will  contribute  to  the  Sustainable 
Development Goals (SDGs) by building resilience for water sector infrastructure, systems, and 
stakeholders. By doing so it will contribute to clean water and sanitation for all (SDG 6), poverty 
reduction (SDG 1), hunger reduction (SDG 2), sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11), and 
action to combat climate change impacts (SDG 13). 
 
5.  With ADB’s water sector projects contributing about 60% to ADB’s total climate adaptation 
financing, proactively targeting climate resilience through adaptation-focused water interventions 
and engagement with clients offers the greatest opportunity to develop more robust, sustainable,

and nature-positive economic development pathways and improved social well-being.5 ADB needs 
to ensure that DMC counterparts can access the required knowledge, capacity, and tools to 
conceptualize, design, and implement climate change adaptation and resilient water projects and 
sector policies. Additional upstream efforts are required at the country level to integrate project 
planning with each country’s nationally determined contributions and long-term strategies, so that 
investment projects are planned with an adaptation focus, rather than simply climate proofing them. 
Integrating ICT and digital and remote sensing tools and technologies has become an important 
and necessary aspect of water resilience, increasingly available at cost-effective prices. The 
COVID-19 pandemic further highlighted the glaring lack of digital technologies for water and 
sanitation service providers and the need to adopt them. The water sector has been slow to adopt 
digital technology, with resistance stemming too often from lack of awareness of what is available 
and affordable. The gender divide is particularly evident in the water sector in service delivery and 
water resources management. Improving water resilience will benefit women and girls since climate 
induced disasters affect them disproportionately as primary care givers.  
 
6.  Building resilience and adaptive capacity is one of the five guiding principles in the 
upcoming ADB water sector framework, 2021–2030.6 In 2021, the WSG prepared a guidance note 
that provides an operational road map to integrate climate resilience into the water sector and DMC 
investment planning and policy development.7 Additional assistance is needed for ADB and its 
clients to implement this road map and these measures, so that current and future water operations 
and programs of ADB and its DMCs can shift their focus towards adaptation and resilience. 
 
7.  Digitalization. To support and spearhead digitalization for water resilience in DMCs, the 
WSG  will  foster  collaboration  with  development  partners,  institutions,  and  private  solution 
providers.  In  March  and  October  2021,  ADB  organized  e-marketplace  events  for  water 
management, bringing together ICT and digital and remote sensing technology solution providers 
and connecting them with water sector DMC clients and staff. The WSG plans to continue such 
events and synthesize solutions, both internal and global best practices, on an interactive virtual 
learning hub for staff and DMC stakeholders. 
 
III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
 
8.  Owing to the increasing need for greater resilience in the water sector, the TA cluster 
modality allows (i) greater flexibility to mobilize resources from multiple funding and knowledge 
partners, and (ii) a harmonized, phased, and holistic approach to supporting DMC clients. 
 
IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
9.  The TA cluster is aligned with the following impact: resilience in the water sector of Asia 
and  the  Pacific  enhanced  (footnote  1).  The  TA  will  have  the  following  outcome:  resilient 
investments and policies in the water sector increased.8 It will help DMCs mainstream water 
resilience by increasing climate adaptation and promoting digitalization through four outputs 
(paras. 10–17).9

10.  Output 1: Climate resilience integrated into water projects, programs, and policies. 
The TA will help DMCs strengthen climate actions in the water sector, particularly on adaptation, 
through all phases of investment planning, policy making, and project preparation. It will help 
integrate climate resilience into water sector investment projects and programs, with a focus on 
group A and B countries, across the full project cycle, emphasizing upstream work to ensure 
climate resilience considerations are incorporated at pre-concept or the earliest possible stage of 
water project development.10 This will help projects embrace climate considerations and DMCs 
build the capacity to transition toward full adaptation type (Type II) projects, which in turn would 
help ensure more robust and resilient development pathways. Support may include: (i) climate 
risk  and  adaptation  assessments;  (ii)  employing  the  latest  technologies  (gray  and  green 
infrastructure) with an emphasis on nature-based solutions, digitalization, and earth observation; 
(iii) review of planning and engineering guidelines; (iv) ensuring that projects and programs are 
Paris Agreement aligned;11 (v) calculating climate adaptation finance; (vi) conducting economic 
and/or financial analysis for adaptation-focused projects, because clients are often concerned 
about additional costs for resilience measures; (vii) assistance with project readiness; and (viii) 
enhancing  the  enabling  environment  and  capacity  to  mobilize  nonsovereign  financing  and 
leveraging access to climate finance from concessional resources. ADB will select DMCs based 
on a comparative needs assessment and following a demand driven approach.  
 
11.  The  TA  will  provide  support  for  water  sector  assessments  for  country  partnership 
strategies and upstream diagnostic work related to water and climate resilience and/or DMC water 
sector or subsector programs that mainstream climate resilience, i.e., long-term strategies and 
sectoral and/or national policies. At national and subnational levels, the TA will strengthen the 
stakeholders’ capacity to plan, budget, deliver, monitor, report, and verify climate outcomes and 
climate finance, particularly on adaptation for the water sector. 
 
12.  Individual consultants and firms will be engaged to assist operations departments and 
DMCs depending on their specific needs. This will include use of a framework agreement for a 
pre-qualified roster of technical specialists or consultants. 
 
13.  Output 2: Digitalization integrated into water management. The TA will support the 
integration of innovative ICT and digital and remote sensing technologies in ADB’s projects and 
programs in two ways:12 
 
(i)  The TA will provide support to selected municipal and village governing bodies, 
utilities, water resource management entities, or other sector-related organizations 
and agencies in DMCs on the use of ICT and digital and remote sensing tools and 
technologies to improve operations. Technologies may include:  
(a)  supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) (traditional and cloud-
based),  hydro-meteorological  measurement  and  information  systems, 
asset mapping and management tools, internet of things and internet of 
people (mobile based) and other ICT and digital technologies for service 
delivery improvement and nonrevenue water reduction in water supply and 
sanitation services delivery; and  
(b)  earth  observation,  remote  sensing,  drone  technologies,  geographic 
information system (GIS), and digitalization to improve water resources

through  increased  agricultural  production,  energy  efficiency,  crop 
efficiency, and irrigation scheduling; improve water quantity and quality 
monitoring, biodiversity monitoring, and tracking of pollution loads and

(ii)  The TA will provide deep dive or handholding support to selected water supply and 
sanitation  service  providers,  water  resource  managers,  and  sector-related 
organizations and agencies on digitalization to improve operations, efficiency, and 
resilience.  These  entities  will  undergo  a  process  of  (a)  gap  identification  or 
diagnostic study and (b) an assessment of needs and readiness for digitalization. 
Support will include identifying entry points for pilot projects and implementing the 
pilot integration of ICT and digital and remote sensing technologies to improve 
resilience and efficiency. Based on the pilots, ADB will prepare an improvement 
and scaling-up plan, including training and capacity-building, to ensure gains 
achieved are sustained and replicated. 
 
14.  Output 3: Capacity development for increased water resilience supported. The TA 
cluster will enhance water sector DMC stakeholders’ capacity to plan and implement resilient 
services as follows: 
 
(i)  The TA will support the establishment of a virtual Asia and the Pacific water 
resilience hub.13 The hub will be a collaborative platform with a water community 
approach to DMC water resilience capacity-building and will facilitate coalitions of 
internal and external stakeholders to leverage collective efforts toward resilience. 
It  will  partner  with  established  knowledge  partners,  universities,  specialized 
training centers, and think tanks on water resilience to assist in tailored training, 
capacity-building,  and  upskilling  DMC  partners’  knowledge  and  skills.  Skills 
mapping  of  selected  DMC  water  clients  will  be  conducted,  with  gender 
disaggregated data, with support from operations departments. The hub may 
develop and provide tailored training courses or capacity enhancement sessions 
through established partners. The hub will include an interactive data and virtual 
capacity enhancement center to enable knowledge sharing and management on 
water resilience for DMCs.  
(ii)  The TA will help enhance DMC water sector stakeholders’ awareness and capacity 
in  climate-resilient  policy  making  and  investment  planning.  It  will  support 
counterparts in line agencies, utilities, local bodies, and planning and finance 
ministries, through workshops, seminars, and/or training to build capacity, create 
an enabling environment, and improve absorptive capacity to (a) balance water-
related investment and infrastructure needs against future risks and consideration 
of climate investment options; (b) enhance access to climate finance; (c) promote

collaboration between stakeholders; (d) develop climate strategies and policies by 
fully addressing environmental and climate change considerations; (e) integrate 
hard infrastructure investments with improved policy making and governance; (f) 
promote environmental sustainability and soft interventions such as nature-based 
solutions;  (g)  promote  the  water-energy-food  nexus;  (h)  promote  institutional 
reforms  in  agencies;  (i)  create  institutional  and  cross-sectoral  incentives  for 
climate-resilient projects; and (j) create development policies and projects that 
promote full adaptation investments. 
The TA cluster will enhance DMC water sector stakeholders’ awareness and 
capacity in ICT and digital and remote sensing resilience through customized 
training courses and/or workshops to share lessons.  
 
15.  Output 4: Support for increased knowledge base on water resilience expanded. The 
TA will help develop and disseminate a range of knowledge products, which will include guidance 
and/or technical notes to support resilient development in the water sector and knowledge products 
to promote resilience tools and technologies. Dissemination will include various modalities, such as 
workshops, seminars, and/or training, use of social media platforms, and production of web-based 
materials, to facilitate wider reach and accessibility beyond the TA duration.  
 
16.  The TA cluster will help produce, share, and manage knowledge through the development 
and dissemination of knowledge products and services for DMC counterparts to better incorporate 
climate resilience in water sector projects, programs, and policies. To improve and standardize 
approaches, the TA will carry out a detailed review of ADB water sector projects to analyze the 
data sources, tools, and approaches used; adaptation and resilience components incorporated; 
and lessons learned. This will be combined with a comparative review of international best 
practices. A knowledge framework will be developed, for the water sector, on aspects such as: (i) 
collation and incorporation of latest climate information and projected medium- to long-term 
climate  change  impacts;14 (ii)  assessment  tools  and  best  practices  for  climate  risks  and 
vulnerability screening; (iii) robust evaluation approaches for incorporating climate uncertainty in 
project design; (iv) tools for conceptualizing and incorporating hard and soft climate resilience 
components  into  project  design;  (v)  detailed  guidance  and  tools  for  aligning  water  sector 
investment projects and programs to the Paris Agreement; (vi) tools for estimating adaptation 
financing ; (vii) cost–benefit considerations and return on investment estimates; (viii) strategies 
for  transforming  projects  with  adaptation  attributes  to  full  adaptation  projects;  (ix)  climate 
adaptation  finance  scaling-up  for  institutional  and/or  intersectoral  incentives;  and  (x) 
understanding the opportunities for climate financing through internal or cofinancing sources. 
 
17.  The TA will support knowledge production, sharing, and management on ICT and digital 
and remote sensing technologies through events such as periodic e-marketplaces to cross 
connect digital solution providers to DMC water sector stakeholders and staff and to share lessons 
from the experiences of water service providers and water resource management organizations. 
It will also support production of knowledge products, such as annual e-newsletters that promote 
tools and technologies on water resilience and security. 
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $5,000,000, of which (i) $2,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund; (ii) $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant basis by

the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB; and (iii) $1,000,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and 
administered by ADB.15 Detailed cost estimates and financing arrangements will be presented in 
each TA subproject proposal submitted for approval. 
 
19.  As of November 2021, the WSG, in collaboration with the Digital Technology Unit of 
SDCC, is also pursuing discussions with the European Space Agency (ESA) to collaborate on 
leveraging on the ESA Global Development Assistance Program to support the TA cluster on 
earth observation components of project proposals from operations departments.  WSG is also 
coordinating with other sector and thematic groups that support integrating digitalization and earth 
observation to strengthen water security and resilience, including the water-food-energy nexus. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  ADB will administer the TA cluster. The WSG, Sector Advisory Service Cluster, will lead 
the TA implementation in collaboration with the operations departments.  Selection of activities 
and  consultant  outputs  under  each  subproject  will  be  closely  coordinated  with  operations 
departments and sector and thematic groups. Each TA subproject proposal will be submitted for 
approval to the Director General of SDCC, following the business process for knowledge and 
support TA cluster processing. Subproject activities will start only after approval. Implementation 
arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

22.  Consulting  services.  Individual  consultants  and  firms  will  be  recruited  to  provide 
international and national consulting inputs. Firms will be recruited using quality- and cost-based 
selection,  quality-based  selection,  fixed  budget  selection,  least-cost  selection,  consultants’ 
qualifications  selection,  or  single  source  selection,  as  appropriate.  The  consultants  will  be 
engaged following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. The estimated cost and 
requisite fields  of  expertise  will  be finalized  before the  approval  of each  TA  subproject  in 
consultation with the participating governments during follow-up missions. 
 
23.  Pilot testing of project approach. Based on demand from operations departments, the 
TA cluster (in particular subprojects 2 and 3) will support pilots on ICT and digital and remote 
sensing technologies including (i) SCADA (traditional and cloud-based), asset mapping and 
management tools, internet of things and internet of people (mobile based); and (ii) a combination 
of earth observation, remote sensing, drone technologies, GIS, and digital integration. Detailed 
implementation arrangements for pilot testing will be finalized before the approval of each TA 
subproject in consultation with the participating governments during follow-up missions. 
 
24.  ADB’s procurement. Procurement of equipment, goods, and works under pilot projects 
will  follow  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  the 
Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). Detailed 
implementation arrangements of ADB procurement will be finalized before the approval of each 
TA  subproject  and a  strategic  procurement  plan  will  be  developed,  where  applicable,  in 
consultation with the participating governments during follow-up missions. 
 
25.  Social media and websites. The TA cluster will coordinate with operations departments 
and beneficiaries on developing content for WSG social media platforms and ADB websites to 
generate and disseminate knowledge, in accordance with ADB guidelines on use of social media. 
 
V.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
26.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction; 
(ii) ADB administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund; 
and (iii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000, for Mainstreaming 
Water Resilience in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

12  Appendix 2 
SUBPROJECT DESCRIPTIONS 
 
Subproject 1  Integrating Climate Resilience in the Water Sector  
Indicative outputs and activities  Output 1: Climate resilience integrated into water sector 
investment projects and programs. The subproject will 
support DMCs in strengthening climate actions in the water 
sector, particularly on adaptation, through all phases of 
investment planning, policy making, and project preparation. It 
will support integration of climate resilience into water sector 
investment projects and programs, with a focus on group A and 
B countries, across the full project cycle, emphasizing upstream 
work to ensure climate resilience considerations are 
incorporated at pre-concept or the earliest possible stage of 
water project development. This will help projects embrace 
climate considerations and DMCs build the capacity to transition 
toward full adaptation type (Type II) projects, which in turn would 
help ensure more robust and resilient development pathways.  
Output 2: Awareness and capacity for climate resilience 
investment planning and policies in the water sector 
enhanced. The subproject will enhance DMC water sector 
stakeholders’ awareness and capacity in climate-resilient policy 
making and investment planning. Counterparts in line agencies, 
utilities, local bodies, as well as planning and finance ministries 
will be supported through workshops, seminars, or training to 
build capacity, create an enabling environment, and improve 
absorptive capacity. 
Output 3: Support for increased knowledge base on climate 
resilience expanded. The subproject will expand knowledge by 
generating and disseminating a range of materials, including 
guidance and technical notes and knowledge products to 
support climate resilience for DMC counterparts to better 
incorporate climate resilience in water sector projects and 
policies. 
Indicative implementation  Individual and firm consultants will be available for operational 
arrangements  staff to access depending on their specific needs. This could 
include use of framework agreement for a pre-qualified roster of 
technical specialists on climate-water sector-related project 
design, climate change adaptation economics, and climate 
adaptation finance, among other things. 
Implementation schedule  November 2021–December 2025 
Subproject 2  Improving Water Security and Resilience through 
Digitalization 
Indicative outputs and activities  Output 1: Digitalization in water sector projects and 
programs integrated. The subproject will provide support to 
operations departments on project preparation and 
implementation by providing assistance to selected municipal 
and village governing bodies, utilities, water resource 
management entities, and/or other water-related organizations 
and agencies in DMCs on integrating ICT and digital and remote 
sensing technologies and innovations to improve operations.

Appendix 2  13 
Support will include identifying entry points or pilot projects and 
implementing the pilot integration of ICT and digital and remote 
sensing technologies to improve resilience and efficiency 
 
Output 2: Asia and the Pacific water resilience hub 
established. The hub will be a collaborative platform with a 
water community approach to DMC’s water resilience capacity-
building and will facilitate coalitions of internal and external 
stakeholders to leverage collective efforts toward resilience. It 
will partner with established knowledge partners, universities, 
specialized training centers, and think tanks on water resilience 
to assist in tailored training, capacity-building and upskilling 
DMC partners’ knowledge and skills, mainly the executing and 
implementing agencies of water projects, water utilities, policy 
makers and resource managers in Asia and the Pacific. Skills 
mapping of selected DMC water clients will be conducted and 
combined with demand from operations departments and 
tailored training courses will be developed and provided to 
selected utilities and water partners. It will include an interactive 
data and virtual capacity enhancement center to enable 
knowledge sharing and management on water resilience for 
ADB’s DMCs. 
Indicative implementation  Individual international and national consultants will be engaged 
arrangements  to respond to the requirements of operations departments and to 
support the TA implementation.  
Implementation schedule  November 2021–December 2025 
Subproject 3  Digitalization of Water Management for Improved Resilience 
Indicative outputs and activities  Output 1: Digitalization integrated into water supply and 
sanitation services delivery and water resources 
management. The subproject will provide deep dive or 
handholding support to water utilities, water resource 
management entities, and/or other sector-related organizations 
and agencies in DMCs in moving on a pathway towards 
digitalization to improve operations, efficiency, and resilience.  
These entities will undergo a process of gap identification or 
diagnostic study, and a needs and readiness assessment 
towards digitalization. Support will include identification of entry 
points for pilots and implementing the pilot integration of ICT and 
digital and remote sensing technologies. Based on the pilots, an 
improvement and scaling-up plan will be prepared, including 
training and capacity-building, to ensure gains achieved are 
sustained and replicated 
 
Output 2: Knowledge sharing and production toward water 
resilience enhanced. This subproject will support a range of 
dissemination materials and modalities. Dissemination materials 
will include knowledge products to promote tools and 
technologies on water resilience and efficiency. Dissemination 
modalities will include workshops, seminars, or training to 
promote learning from the experiences of water service 
providers and water resource management organizations, use of 
social media platforms, and production of web-based materials, 
among other things, to facilitate wider reach and accessibility 
beyond the TA duration.

arrangements  capacity development program and individual international and 
national consultants to support subproject implementation.
